extendedInfo.description: Home Inventory Checklist is to maintain an inventory of the items in your house using your device very easily. It will be helpful if you ever have an insurance claim. Preparing a list before something happens is easier than trying to write a list from memory later. A detailed inventory can also speed up the claims process and help prove tax deductible, uninsured losses. You can email the list to yourself for safe keeping of your records. You can continue to update the list as new items are added or old items discarded.Make your inventory as complete and detailed as possible. Your insurance company will require a detailed list of your personal property before paying your claim. Update your inventory regularly to add new items.List purchase dates, values, serial numbers and brand names for items when possible. Keep receipts for expensive items.Following are the features:1. Notice how many items added in each category.2. Upload item level photos.3. You can send Home Inventory report to your personal email.4. You can see report any time briefly in email attachment.

reviews.title: Great App, could be developed further
reviews.comment: Basic functionality is exactly what I need. Functions to add: picture tags as \"item\", \"receipt\", and \"warranty\"; generic field additions; management of a master field list. Then of course working on the GUI a bit. The basic functionality gives it a 4 out of 5.
reviews.author: A Google User

reviews.comment: Crashes all the time when accessing an item.
reviews.author: A Google User

reviews.title: Garbage
reviews.comment: I installed today and all this piece of garbage did was to constantly freeze up. My patience grew short and I  uninstalled this garbage. Could be a keeper because it has some could uses.
reviews.author: A Google User

reviews.title: Stand alone
reviews.comment: Its a great private no permissions app
reviews.author: A Google User

reviews.title: galaxy note 2
reviews.comment: Set up for this program is good. Camera angles and shots are bad.
